div.p:
To proof. Bot names to check.
Easter 1896.

The "Hurdy Saltbush" N. 5, sent by you, dear Mr Tyson, is perhaps the Atriplex hymenothecum (of Moquin-Tandon). This species is very imperfectly known, altho' I figured it in my large work on Australian Salt-Bushes. Your specimens are all male, the female plant is distinct, as in several other kinds of Atriplex. The fruit of A. hymenothecum is comparatively large.
I had good female specimens, but never well developed males.

As you call it "Hurdy", I presume it is of climbing Habit. Please tell me, whether it is a superior
saltbush for sheep. If so, I will insert it on your authority into the next edition of the "Select Plants". It may be too slender to be of much use. You are sure to find some female plants near to the males. If so, please send branchlets with ripe fruits If these are different from those of the true A. hymenothecum, then this species of yours will be new and be named after you.

Herewith I send you a plate of A. paludosum from my work on Saltbushes. You will see 2 male plants on the plate, and to the right a sprig of a female plant. Any how I should like to have seeds well ripened of this Atriplex of yours, as it has never yet been in cultivation

Can I reckon, that you and your kind brother will pick up for me all sorts of
minute plants this season?

div.p: If your Atriplex with the clusters of male flowers is A. hymenothecum, then we had it never from so far north. Perhaps it ranges into the tropics. What a pity that not some one about Capricorn collects and dries plants. It is so little trouble in the dry inland clime.
I fancy you must have many different kinds of Saltbushes in your region
